item.title: 10 Things I Love About My Kids
item.description: Lest my previous parenting post suggest that things are all doom-and-gloom at the Steele-haus, here are 10 things I love about my kids. I got to baptize all 3 of them as babies, a poignant reminder that they are beloved children of God. They all love books, which warms my nerdy heart. The way Eleanor (1yo) greets me. It used to be a very excited squeal. Now it‚Äôs ‚ÄúAh! Daddy!‚Äù Andrew (4yo) has a great memory for stories, especially Bible stories.

item.title: I Love My Kids, But I Sometimes Regret Having Them
item.description: I love my kids, but I sometimes regret having them. Pardon the clickbait-y title and opening sentence. But are we parents allowed to say that? Are we allowed to feel both of those things at once? We‚Äôve got a 6-year-old, a 4-year-old, and an almost-2-year-old. And, no, I don‚Äôt actually begrudge them their existence! I want what‚Äôs best for their lives and futures. And don‚Äôt get me wrong; there are moments of laughter, poignancy, joy, etc.

item.title: Know Thyself: Unveiling Your Unique Strengths and Personality Traits
item.description: In the quest for personal and professional growth, understanding our unique strengths and personality traits can be incredibly enlightening. Today, I want to share my insights from various personality paradigms and how they shape my approach to work and life. CliftonStrengths: Harnessing Core Talents The CliftonStrengths assessment has been instrumental in identifying my core talents. Here are my top five strengths: Input: I have an insatiable curiosity and a constant desire to collect information.

item.description: I‚Äôve often enjoyed lifting weights, but I‚Äôve never enjoyed going to the gym. So, I‚Äôve long wanted a nice home gym. item.title: Back in the Saddle
item.description: I know I‚Äôm not alone in this, but the past few years have been pretty rough for me. I‚Äôve gained at least 50 pounds. I had a fun part-time gig as a managing editor come to an end. I‚Äôve come to terms with some long-term depression and anxiety. I had a job offer ripped out from under me. I hit pause on and eventually dropped out of my Ph.D. program. I‚Äôve resigned from ordained ministry in the ACNA, my previous denomination.

item.title: I'm Resigning from Ordained Ministry in the Anglican Church in North America
item.description: After a considerable period of discernment, coupled with my growing disaffection with the Anglican Church in North America, I sense God calling me to step away from ordained ministry in the ACNA and instead to focus on my family and my career as a software engineer. This also coincides with plans to move closer to family in NW Ohio (where there is not much of an ACNA presence to speak of) and to then pursue church involvement outside of the ACNA.

item.title: Life Lessons: 32 Things I've Learned So Far
item.description: Here are 32 things I‚Äôve learned from life, so far. You are not your thoughts. There is a ‚Äúyou‚Äù behind and above your inner voice/monologue/dialogue. Pay attention to what you pay attention to. Think about what you think about. We always only have the present moment. Focusing too much on the future leads to anxiety. Focusing too much on the past leads to depression. Wherever you are, be fully there, now!

item.title: My Coding Bootcamp Journey: How a Pastor Became a Programmer
item.description: When I changed my major from Mechanical Engineering to Bible shortly before my first semester of college, I realized that what I was studying was not going to make me rich. So, throughout undergrad, seminary, and into a Ph.D. program in theology, the notion of ‚Äúbi-vocational ministry‚Äù (serving the church while also making money outside of the church doing something else) was on my radar screen. In fact, for a few months between finishing seminary and starting my Ph.

item.title: What Color is My Parachute? The Flower Petal Exercise
item.description: I‚Äôm working my way through the classic job search guide What Color Is Your Parachute. First, I‚Äôll summarize the 7-part ‚ÄúFlower Petal‚Äù exercise‚Äîa comprehensive self-assessment geared toward the workplace. Then, I‚Äôll share *my* results from the self-assessment. Ah, but first, my TL;DR: If you‚Äôre looking for work, or going to be looking for work soon, do yourself a huge favor and buy the latest edition of What Color Is Your Parachute.

item.title: It's Official. I'm Hitting Pause on My Ph.D. for a Year
item.description: I received word yesterday that the Ph.D. Committee voted to approve my request for ‚ÄúExcused Program Leave‚Äù beginning in January 2021 and lasting until January 2022. At the risk of sounding like Captain Obvious, 2020 has been a particularly difficult year. Attempting to complete my ‚ÄúBarth, Bonhoeffer, and the Bible‚Äù dissertation has taken a toll on my mental health as I ran into some major research and writing roadblocks right before and during the COVID pandemic.

item.title: I'm looking for a new role to supplement my part-time work for Anglican Compass
item.description: Hey everyone! Just a brief update to note that I‚Äôm looking for a new role to supplement my part-time work as Managing Editor of Anglican Compass! I‚Äôm pretty flexible at this point, but I want to do something that benefits the church. I think I would make a great Assistant Rector! üôÇ Any advice, opportunities, or connections you can offer would be appreciated! You can view/share my CV here. And here‚Äôs my LinkedIn profile.

item.title: Josh+? On the use of the sign of the cross (plus sign) in clergy signatures
item.description: This is, admittedly, a half-baked opinion. However, I need to get back in the habit of blogging/writing regularly, so here goes. In my opinion, the use of the sign of the cross in clergy names/signatures‚Äîunless it‚Äôs done in official ecclesiastical communication or immediately after a blessing or prayer for the recipient‚Äîis pretentious. It‚Äôs showy. At the very least, it conveys or connotes pretentiousness. Note that I‚Äôm not making a claim about the *people* who use crosses in their signatures, their inner thoughts, or their intentions.

item.title: It's Time to Get Some Help
item.description: Due to increased symptoms of depression and anxiety in recent weeks, I‚Äôve decided to try out a combination of counseling and medication. Sure, I‚Äôve still been able to get out of bed in the morning. And I wasn‚Äôt having any serious thoughts about hurting myself. But still, I was feeling hopeless and trapped often enough that I decided it was time to seek out help. I know, I know. That‚Äôs pretty personal for a blog post for the whole internet to read!

item.title: A Prayer for Trustfulness in Times of Worry and Anxiety
item.description: I needed this prayer this morning, and I plan to return to it often in the days ahead. Most loving Father, you will us to give thanks for all things, to dread nothing but the loss of you, and to cast all our care on the One who cares for us. Preserve us from faithless fears and worldly anxieties, and grant that no clouds of this mortal life may hide from us the light of that love which is immortal, and which you have manifested unto us in your Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.

item.title: First Day of 24th Grade!
item.description: Not sure how this is going to go, or even why I‚Äôm doing this anymore, but here we go! Still praying for either a dissertation break-through or a clear sign that I should quit. I hope to receive or discover one of those before the end of the calendar year.

item.title: It‚Äôs time for another social media fast!
item.description: After listening to the Blinkist summary of Cal Newport‚Äôs Deep Work (I‚Äôve read the book, this was just for a refresher), I‚Äôm convinced that it‚Äôs time for another 30-day fast from Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram. I think I‚Äôll still keep my micro.blog up and running, but between running Anglican Compass and sprinting for some last-ditch clarity on my increasingly frustrating dissertation, I need all the extra bandwidth I can get!

item.title: The Ph.D. Plan (Or the Lack Thereof)
item.description: For months and months now, I‚Äôve been praying for either (1) a breakthrough on my ‚ÄúBarth, Bonhoeffer, and the Bible‚Äù dissertation or (2) a clear sign that I should quit the Ph.D. Unfortunately, after countless confusing dead ends in my endeavors to put Karl Barth and Dietrich Bonhoeffer into precise conversation with each other regarding specific passages of the Bible, I‚Äôve now realized that such an approach is not going to work.

item.description: My Bishop, Todd Hunter, preached [an excellent, challenging sermon (‚ÄúLove Your Enemies, Really?‚Äù)](https://friendsofthesavior.org/sermons/love-your-enemies-really-bishop-todd-hunter). It‚Äôs definitely worth a listen!

item.title: Help me achieve my home gym dream

item.title: Use Rapoport's Rules for Better Conversations and Disagreements
item.description: I‚Äôm reading Walter Sinnott-Armstrong‚Äôs excellent book, Think Again: How to Reason and Argue. In it (on pages 25‚Äì26), I came across ‚ÄúRapoport‚Äôs Rules.‚Äù First formulated by mathematical psychologist Anatol Rapoport and discussed by Daniel Dennett (Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thinking, 31‚Äì35), here they are: 1: You should attempt to re-express your target‚Äôs position so clearly, vividly, and fairly that your target says, ‚ÄúThanks, I wish I‚Äôd thought of putting it that way.

item.title: Women's Ordination Debates in Anglicanism: The 2017 ACNA Report and the 2003 AMIA Report
item.description: I became an ‚Äúegalitarian‚Äù in college, before I became an Anglican in seminary. It‚Äôs taken some time for me to get used to the different contours of the women‚Äôs ordination debate within Anglicanism. Growing up, the debate was all about particular Bible verses and whether or not women could teach and preach. However, in Anglicanism, although those same questions/arguments are present, I hear much more about whether or not women can administer the sacraments as priests.

item.title: Eva Joy Steele: A Birth Story
item.description: This is a self-indulgently long story. The gist of it is that my wife, Rachel, was unexpectedly induced due to gestational hypertension at 37 weeks, right before we were supposed to head to Pennsylvania for her sister‚Äôs wedding. After a lengthy induction and labor, our beautiful daughter, Eva Joy Steele, was born at 5:46am on Friday, July 20, 2018. If that‚Äôs all you‚Äôd like to know, great! If you‚Äôd like to know more about what went down, keep reading.

item.title: Please Don't Leave Me Alone: On Male Friendships, or the Lack Thereof
item.description: Maybe you, like me, consider yourself quite the introvert. Maybe you, like me, have a difficult time walking the tightrope between feeling quickly overwhelmed by interpersonal relationships, on the one hand, and feeling incredibly lonely, on the other hand. Maybe you, like me, feel these problems acutely as a male (although I‚Äôm sure that females are having their own relational struggles as our culture increasingly pressures us all to be ‚Äúalone together,‚Äù looking at our screens instead of looking each other in the eye).

item.title: Getting back on the "Getting Things Done" Productivity Bandwagon
item.description: Getting Things Done (‚ÄúGTD‚Äù for short) is a wildly popular personal productivity system invented and popularized by David Allen. However, as Nicole Dieker at Lifehacker pointed out in 2017, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt hear a lot of people talk about the Getting Things Done productivity system anymore.‚Äù I think that‚Äôs a shame, because it‚Äôs a very effective system. I first tried Getting Things Done after reading ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs Best Next‚Äù by Matt Perman, and then reading ‚ÄúGetting Things Done‚Äù by David Allen (in its newly revised 2015 edition) shortly thereafter.

item.title: This Song is a Beautiful Picture of the Theological Journey
item.description: I was recently privileged to see one of my favorite bands, The Oh Hellos, in concert at the House of Blues in downtown Chicago. I love all of The Oh Hellos‚Äô music, but one song, in particular, has remained poignant to me ever since I first heard it. The song is called ‚ÄúThe Truth is a Cave,‚Äù and I think it provides a beautiful picture of what I‚Äôm calling ‚Äúthe theological journey‚Äù ‚Äì the stages one goes through in one‚Äôs knowledge of God.

item.title: Dangerous Beauty: Phoenix and Grand Canyon Trip 2018
item.description: Rachel and I just got back from our very first trip to the Southwest. The main reason for the trip was to visit some good friends of ours, the Smith family, in Phoenix, AZ. Here‚Äôs a picture of the group of us together after church at Living Faith Anglican Church in Tempe, AZ, where my friend Peter Smith is the rector. The trip was a blast. It was great to catch up with the Smiths and to see their new home and church in Arizona.

item.title: 3 Confessions of an Expectant Father
item.description: We‚Äôre Expecting! In case you haven‚Äôt heard the news, my wife Rachel and I are expecting our firstborn child this August! Rachel is currently 16 weeks along, and we won‚Äôt find out the gender of the baby (whom I am affectionately calling ‚ÄúLump‚Äù) for another month. The last few months have been quite busy for us since we found out Rachel is pregnant. She works full-time as a Family Nurse Practitioner.

item.title: Testimony: A Faith Story, In Brief
item.description: The following is an attempt to tell my testimony, the story of my Christian faith, in approximately 500 words. It was challenging to do, but also a helpful exercise! I challenge you to write out your own story in approximately 500 words. Testimony For as long as I can remember, I have known and followed Jesus Christ as my Lord and Savior. However, there has been a lingering problem in our relationship ‚Äì on my end.

item.title: Thank God, I Went to Cedarville

item.title: How Do You Want To Be Remembered?
item.description: Do you know what the worst thing about death is? It‚Äôs not the dying itself ‚Äì its the separation. That is, we don‚Äôt suffer the most from our own deaths (a one-time occurrence), but from suffering the deaths of others (repeatedly). Instead of living relationships, we are left with distant memories. A sad reality, to be sure. What if, however, we could use death to our own advantage? I‚Äôm convinced this is the truth behind Ecclesiastes 7:2 ‚Äì

item.title: What are you afraid of?
item.description: I‚Äôm scared. Are you? Specifically, as I wrote in my journal this very morning: I‚Äôm scared ‚Äì I‚Äôm scared of wasting my life, I‚Äôm scared of not being worth anything outside of the classroom. Fear drives so many aspects of our lives ‚Äì from how we dress, to how we raise our children, to how we elect our leaders. And, if we‚Äôre honest with ourselves, fear can play a large role in what/whom we worship.

item.title: My Uncle, Timothy Steele
item.description: (This post is about my late uncle, Timothy Steele. It‚Äôs long, and I swear toward the end. Sorry.) ‚ÄúIt is better to go to a funeral than a feast. For death is the destiny of every person, and the living should take this to heart. Sorrow is better than laughter, because sober reflection is good for the heart.‚Äù (Ecclesiastes 7:2-3) Timothy Steele The juxtaposition is staggering. The funeral of the man I most associate with laughter and joy.

item.title: Presenting on Karl Barth at 2015 Southeastern ETS

item.title: On Building/Burning Bridges
item.description: DISCLAIMER: there‚Äôs a fair bit about the Church that frustrates me. However, I‚Äôd like to address those frustrations in a way that builds bridges, not burns them down. Especially since sin and justice are both relational. It does no good to flee the former for the latter in a way that creates more rifts than it heals. Therefore, any criticisms I level against my sisters and brothers in Christ, (many of those criticisms coming from outside the walls of the Church), I‚Äôd like first to aim them at myself.

item.title: Let There Be Light: My Resignation
item.description: **Please read: Let There Be Light ‚Äì Leadership Transfer** Until further notice, I hereby rescind my use of the Let There Be Light platform (including blog, Facebook, and Twitter) to protest recent changes at Cedarville University. The LTBL platform will now be exclusively alumni-run, and I encourage everyone interested in developments at the University to follow their posts and make subsequent judgments regarding Cedarville‚Äôs identity and vision. My goal in all of this is to honor my Messiah by following him well and furthering his Kingdom with justice, unity, and true peace.

item.title: Open Apology
item.description: To whomever the following concerns: I‚Äôd like to apologize publicly to any persons I may have offended during the past few months of my student activism efforts at Cedarville University. After all, I recognize that some of my statements/claims about the perceived injustices at my University have seemed quite shocking, especially without further context. So I apologize for the times when I put pithiness before precision and unwittingly ostracized many good people whom I was not intending to criticize at all.

item.title: For shame, Cedarville

item.title: Open Letter to Cedarville Admins and Trustees
